questions.question: In a patient who has completed the 3rd stage of labor following vaginal delivery, what is theminimum amount of blood loss required for her to be diagnosed with postpartumhemorrhage?
A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery.What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.explanation: Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.400Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helpsto arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.Types of PPH:• Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the mostcommon cause of primary PPH.●Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retainedplacenta is the most common cause.The risk factors for atonic uterus include:• Primiparity or grand multiparity• Previous PPH• Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia• Precipitate labour• Prolonged labour• Uterine malformations• Uterine fibroid•••Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocinPlacental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placentaObesity• Age >40 yearsNote: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most probable cause of bleeding per vaginum occurring 24hours after delivery?
questions.explanation: Retained cotyledon is the most probable cause of late or secondary PPH i.e., bleeding that occursafter 24 hours of delivery.Other options are causes of early PPH.Types of PPH include:Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. The causes are: (mnemonic4T)•Tone: Atonic PPH (80%)• Trauma: Traumatic PPH• Thrombin: Coagulopathy• Tissue: retained products of conceptionRisk Factors for primary PPH:Atonic PPH:401• Primiparity or grand multiparity• Previous PPH•⚫ Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia• Precipitate labour• Prolonged labour• Uterine malformations• Uterine fibroid•Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin• Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placenta•Obesity•Age >40 yearsTraumatic PPH:• Instrumental delivery•Episiotomy• Precipitate labour• MacrosomiaCoagulopathy:•⚫ Sepsis• IUD• HELLP syndromeSecondary/late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum.Causes include:•Retained parts of cotyledon or membranes• Endometritis• Abnormal involution of placental site• Secondary haemorrhage from caesarean section wound• Placental polyp• Infected fibroid• Uterine AV fistula• Puerperal uterine inversion• Carcinoma cervix.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH?393
questions.explanation: 402Placenta previa does not cause secondary postpartum hemorrhage. It causes primary postpartumhemorrhage.Types of PPH:Primary/early: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth.Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum.Causes and risk factors for PPH:The image below shows the prevention and management of PPH:Primary PPHAtonic PPHSecondary PPHTraumatic PPHCoagulopathyInstrumental deliverSepsisyRetained bits of cotyledon ormembranesPrimiparity or grand multiparityPlacental abnormalities like p Precipitate labourlacenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placentaOverdistended uterus as in mMacrosomiaulti-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomiaInduction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocinProlonged labourPrecipitate labourPrevious h/o PPHObesityAge >40 yearsEpisiotomyHELLP synd Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section woundromeIUDPuerperal uterine inversionFIGO recommendationsPrevention and treatment of PPHAbnormal involution of placental siteInfected fibroidEndometritisPlacental polypCarcinoma of cervixUterine av fistulaPreventionAMTSL (Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor)Uterotonic agent administrationControlled cord tractionUterine massagePost partum haemorrhageVaginal delivery >500 mL of blood lossCesarean delivery >1L of blood lossMTreatmentControl bleedingAortic compressionUterine tamponade for atonySecure IV accessIf ongoing bleedingMonitor maternal statusAirway, Breathing, and CirculationIV accessCrystalloidsOxytocin 20-40 IU/L IV fluid infusionBlood products if availableUterine massageWExamination to determine cause of bleedingUterineatonyUterotonicsIf failedIntrauterine tamponadeShock trousersUterine arteryembolizationLaparotomyRetainedplacentaManually removalof placentaUterineinversionManuallyreplace uterusIf failedDilation andcurettageIf failedSurgeryMARROW403LacerationsRepair alllacerationsIf failedHypogastricartery ligationB-Lynch suturesHysterectomy

questions.question: Which of the following complications during pregnancy does not increase the risk of PPH?
questions.explanation: Oligohydramnios does not increase the risk of PPH. However, polyhydramnios can increase therisk by causing uterine atony, due to an overdistended uterus.Risk factors for primary PPH:Atonic PPH:•Primiparity or grand multiparity• Previous PPH⚫ Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia• Precipitate labour• Prolonged labour• Uterine malformations• Uterine fibroid• Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin• Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta•ObesityAge >40 yearsTraumatic PPH:••• Instrumental delivery⚫ Episiotomy• Precipitate labour• MacrosomiaCoagulopathy:•Sepsis• IUD• HELLP syndromeCauses of secondary PPH:•Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes• Endometritis• Abnormal involution of placental site• Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section wound.• Placental polyp• Infected fibroid404• Uterine av fistula• Puerperal uterine inversion• Carcinoma cervix.

questions.question: In a patient with GDM complicating pregnancy, there was severe bleeding following thedelivery of the placenta. On abdominal palpation, the fundus felt soft and later became hardon massaging. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.explanation: In the above scenario, a soft uterus that becomes hard on massaging indicates an atonic uterus.Uterine rupture is a risk factor of traumatic PPH, not atonic PPH.Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Thus, bleeding fromthe placental implantation site is not arrested.GDM complicating pregnancy can cause macrosomia, which is a risk factor of this condition.Risk factors for atonic PPH:•Primiparity or grand multiparity• Previous PPH• Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia•Precipitate labour•Prolonged labour• Uterine malformations• Uterine fibroid• Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin• Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta•Obesity•Age >40 years

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor toprevent postpartum hemorrhage?

options.B: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.explanation: As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Managementof the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartumhemorrhage (PPH).Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH inwomen who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component ofAMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterineatony as a part of the management of PPH.AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics arethe most important components in AMTSL to do so.The currently recommended components of AMTSL are as follows:405Note: In the event that uterine atony is diagnosed during the assessment of uterine tone, uterinemassage can be performed to control PPH.1.234Injectinguterotonicswithin1minuteof delivery of the babyor immediately after deliveryof theanterior shoulderDelayed cord clampingDelivery of placenta by controlled cord traction: ModifiedBrandt Andrews techniqueIntermittent assessment of uterine toneMost importantstepOxytocin10 IU im/iv infusion is thepreferred uterotonic. (Not recommendedby WHO-carboprost)Done within1-3 minsof delivery80 mlof additional blood goes to the fetus PreventsfetalanemiaThe uterus is pushed upwards and backwardThe traction of cord is downwards and forwardsDone every 15 mins for 2 hours

questions.question: 394A patient with pre-eclampsia presents with profuse bleeding after delivery. Which of thefollowing drugs can be used in the medical management of this patient?
questions.explanation: PPH in a patient with pre-eclampsia can be treated with misoprostol. It is a PGE1 analogue usedas a second line uterotonic in the treatment of PPH.The drug of choice for PPH in normal patients is oxytocin.Option A: Methergine and other ergot derivatives cause dangerous hypertension in pre-eclampsia.Options B and D: Carboprost and Dinoprost cause severe hypertension in pre-eclampsia.Medical Management of PPH:DrugDoseSide effectsContraindicationsOxytocin10-40 U in 1L crystalloid (never given as iv bolus)Water intoxicationMethergi0.2 mgHypertensionPre-eclampsianeCarbopro0.25 mg (8 doses max)Diarrhoea Hypertension VomisttingBronchial asthmaCardiac, renal or hepatic diseasesMisopros600-1000 mcgFever Tachycardiatol

questions.question: In a case of atonic PPH, a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative was given every 15 mins as auterotonic. What is the maximum number of times the drug can be administered?
questions.explanation: Carboprost is a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum doseis 2mg.406So, 2/0.258 times.Carboprost is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPHthat is unresponsive to oxytocin.Side effects:• Diarrhoea.• Hypertension•• Nausea• VomitingContraindications:• Bronchial asthma••Suspected amniotic fluid embolism• Active cardiac, renal or hepatic diseases.

questions.question: As per 2017 WHO guidelines for the treatment of PPH, which of the following statements istrue?

options.A: Uterine massage is not recommended in PPH when oxytocin is administered
options.B: Intravenous colloids are the recommended fluids for initial resuscitation
options.C: If the PPH is not responsive to uterotonics, uterine artery embolisation is the next step
options.D: Tranexamic acid is administered early in all cases of PPH

questions.explanation: Early administration of tranexamic acid is done in all cases of PPH.Tranexamic acid for the treatment of PPH is used as follows:• Tranexamic acid should be given in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause.•Early use of iv tranexamic acid (i.e) within 3 hours of birth• Fixed-dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) iv at 1 mL per minute•If bleeding continues after 30 minutes, the second dose of 1 g iv is givenOption A: Uterine massage must be done in addition to oxytocin in all cases of PPH. This will helpin the contraction of an atonic uterus. In normal patients, uterine massage is not compulsory asper AMTSL.Option B: IV crystalloids are the recommended fluids for resuscitation.Option C: Balloon tamponade is the next step after uterotonics.

questions.question: Following normal vaginal delivery, a patient developed PPH and lost about 700mL of blood.Her PR was 100 bpm and her BP was 100/60mmHg. What is the value and correspondinginterpretation of her shock index?
questions.explanation: Shock index = 1 and it indicates significant blood loss.The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP.Here, PR=100 and systolic BP=100.Shock Index = 100/100 = 1-If the shock index is 0.9 – 1.1, it indicates massive blood loss and the need for intensiveresuscitation.407DescriptionNormal value of shock index(non-pregnant)Range of shock index0.5-0.7Normal value of shock index0.7-0.8in pregnant (i.e) Obstetrical shock indexSignificant or massive blood 10.9 - 1.1OSS

questions.question: A patient was referred to the casualty from a district hospital with atonic PPH. Which of thefollowing measures is least likely to be done?

options.B: Use non-pneumatic anti-shock garment to stabilize the patient

questions.explanation: Using a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) is not one of the first measures for themanagement of atonic PPH. NASG is used to reduce bleeding and stabilize the patient for shiftingto tertiary centers.The below image shows a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment.223NASGNON-PNEUMATICCAUTIONNon-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) works by applying circumferential counterpressure. Itdecreases blood flow to the abdomen, pelvis, and lower extremities. It increases the blood flow tothe heart, lungs, and brain.First step measures in the management of PPH must be done immediately and simultaneously.This includes:•Continuous iv oxytocin infusion• Fundal massage and bimanual uterine compression• Volume resuscitation with crystalloids• Insertion of Foley's catheter to monitor urine output408• Alert the anesthesia team to begin a manual exploration of the uterus under GA to check for:• Retained placental fragments•• Uterine abnormalities• Lacerations• Rupture• Blood transfusion should be done if vitals are still unstableIf bleeding still continues, further steps are taken depending on the patient profile:●• Balloon tamponade•Surgical methods:• B lynch compression sutures• Uterine artery ligation••• Internal iliac artery ligationAngiographic embolization• Hysterectomy.

questions.question: A 35-year-old multipara with atonic PPH continues to bleed profusely despite medicalmanagement and tamponade. Which of the following methods cannot be used to reducebleeding in this patient?
questions.explanation: Thermal endometrial ablation is a treatment modality for Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB). It isnot used in the treatment of PPH.In patients who are unresponsive to initial resuscitation and medical management, the followingmethods can be used:••• Balloon tamponadeSurgical methods:• B lynch compression sutures• Uterine artery ligation••• Internal iliac artery ligationAngiographic embolization• Hysterectomy.

questions.question: Identify the instrument in the image given below.396
questions.explanation: The image shows a Bakri balloon. It is used in uterine tamponade in patients with atonic PPHwho are unresponsive to medical management.The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterinecavity.409Bakri balloonMARROWOMARROWIt acts by stimulating uterine contraction and direct hemostatic pressure to the open uterinesinuses (tamponade effect).The maximum capacity of the balloon is 500mL. It is inflated with normal saline (200-500mL)and can be retained for up to 12 hours. Success rates are high and it can be used to avoidhysterectomy.Other options: Sengstaken Blakemore tube, condom catheter, and 34F Foley with 60mL balloonare other instruments that can be used for uterine tamponade.The image below depicts Sengstaken Blakemore tube.MARROWThe image below depicts Foley's catheter.OMARROW41010ml16Fr/6.0 mm- Sizein french scale& millimeters-BalloonUrine drainage port→ Balloon portvolume of fluid recommended toInflate balloon markedBladder openingColourcodeSize inFR/CHLight blue8Black10White12Green14Orange16OMARROWColourcodeSize inFR/CHRed18Yellow20Violet22Blue24

questions.question: What is the capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH?
questions.explanation: The capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH is 300 to 500 mL.Bakri balloon is used in uterine tamponade in cases of atonic PPH unresponsive to medicalmanagement.Insertion of Bakri balloon requires three team members.••One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure.Another member places the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilizes it.The third member instills fluid to inflate the balloon.Initially, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL of normal saline is done. It is followed by furtherinfusion over a few minutes up to 300 to 500 mL.Bakri postpartum balloon tamponadeMA©MARROW411

questions.question: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion.The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression.She becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.explanation: Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medicalmanagement and bimanual uterine massage.Bakri postpartum balloon tamponadeM©MARROWOption A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealedbleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient totertiary care centers.Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compressionsutures).Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually,the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy isdone sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

questions.question: A pregnant lady delivered her baby unattended while she was on the way to the hospital.While examining her, you note a perineal tear in which the anal sphincter is disrupted. Thistear is classified as
questions.explanation: The perineal tears in which anal sphincter is disrupted are classified as third-degree perineal tear.

questions.question: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
questions.explanation: Image 1 depicts B lynch suture.412Uterine compression suturesB lynch sutureture RRCho square suturesHayman sutureOMARROWPereira sutureAll these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose thewalls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.

questions.question: A patient with severe PPH is shifted to the emergency OT for B lynch compression sutures.Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

options.A: The suture loops over the fundus
options.D: Uterine ischaemic necrosis is a complication

questions.explanation: The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures and it is used in atonic PPH.B lynch suture is a technique to arrest hemorrhage in severe postpartum atony.Duriyou may hThe suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over thefundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundusand taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends aretied in a surgical knot.The uterus is compressed antero-posteriorly.413The success rate is high.Ischaemic uterine necrosis is a complication of this procedure.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2 and 3 are true.Statement 4: Hematomas <5 cm can be managed conservatively with cold compress. Largerhematomas need to be explored surgically.Statement 5: Lower uterine segment rupture causes supra-levator hematoma.Types of pelvic hematomas:FeatureIncidenceLocationCausesSupralevator hematomaInfralevator hematomaCommonRareBelow the levator aniImproper hemostasis duringrepair of vaginal/ perineal tears or episiotomy woundSevere pain with rectal tenesmusPresentationTreatmentSmall hematomas can be conservatively managed with cold compressAbove the levator aniExtension of cervical laceration, lower uterine segment ruptureUnexplained shock with features of internal haemorrhageLaparotomy

questions.question: In a patient with hydramnios complicating pregnancy, the third stage of labour was managedby applying fundal pressure and controlled traction of the cord. On palpation, the uterus wasstill soft and boggy. Within a few minutes, there was moderate bleeding per vaginumfollowing which a reddish-purple mass was expelled. The patient then developed hypotension,bradycardia and went into shock. What is the most probable diagnosis?

options.B: Atonic postpartum haemorrhageUterine inversiond) Placenta accretaQuestion 22:Which among the following is the most potent drug to control PPH?a) Oxytocinb) Methergin

questions.explanation: The most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion.Hydramnios is a risk factor for uterine inversion due to uterine over-distension. Fundal pressurewhile the uterus is atonic (soft, relaxed, and boggy) causes uterine inversion. It results inhaemorrhage followed by complete uterine inversion protruding out of the vulva. Neurogenic typeof shock develops due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament and the ovaries.Option A: Amniotic fluid embolism causes cardiac arrest, acute hypoxia and severe haemorrhage.Option B: There was only moderate bleeding per vaginum and soft uterus. But since there isprotrusion of the uterus per vaginum, the most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion.Option D: Placenta accreta rarely causes uterine inversion.Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor,in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely.Causes:• Most common cause is mismanagement of 3rd stage of labour414• Spontaneous• Placenta accreta (rarely)Features:• Shock immediately after delivery• The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding• Shock is either neurogenic or hemorrhagic• Per abdomen examination fundus of the uterus is not palpable.Management of uterine inversion:Vaginal operationsKustnerAbdominal operationsHuntingtonsSpinelliHaultainHydrostatic methodO SullivanOguch
